texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If this situation pops up in Plesk, it means that a user has changed their MySQL password outside of Plesk. The password in Plesk's own database does not match, so the auto-creation of the phpMyAdmin settings fails. You'll end up seeing this after clicking "DB WebAdmin":
texts.text: If this situation pops up in Plesk, it means that a user has changed their MySQL password outside of Plesk. The password in Plesk's own database does not match, so the auto-creation of the phpMyAdmin settings fails. You'll end up seeing this after clicking "DB WebAdmin":

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: MySQL said: Non-static method PMA_Config::isHttps() should not be called statically
texts.text: MySQL said: Non-static method PMA_Config::isHttps() should not be called statically

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The funny thing is that MySQL doesn't actually say this. It's a PHP error. To correct the problem, you can manually change the password within Plesk's database, or you can follow an easier method:
texts.text: The funny thing is that MySQL doesn't actually say this. It's a PHP error. To correct the problem, you can manually change the password within Plesk's database, or you can follow an easier method:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Click the user that has a password change
texts.text: Click the user that has a password change

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In the password fields, enter the new password that they're using with MySQL
texts.text: In the password fields, enter the new password that they're using with MySQL

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This will force Plesk to change its password in its own database, and it will run the query to change the password in MySQL (but since it's the same password, no change will be made).
texts.text: This will force Plesk to change its password in its own database, and it will run the query to change the password in MySQL (but since it's the same password, no change will be made).
